title-group.article-title: Liberation Theology's Critique of the Developmentalist Worldview
title-group.subtitle: Implications for Religious Environmental Engagement

bio.p: Stephen Scharper is Assistant Professor with the Centre for Environment and Centre for the Study of Religion at the University of Toronto. His current research, funded by the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada, entails exploring the interconnection of liberation theology, with its emphasis on structural poverty, and ecological theology, especially in its cosmological emphases. He is also, with Ingrid Leman Stefanovic, co-editing a book on The Natural City, forthcoming from the University of Toronto Press.

abstract.p: As the world's religious communities become more involved in environmental concerns, the question arises as to whether their most significant contributions are in the realm of worldviews, doctrine, and cosmology, or rather in the realm of political and economic critique and an articulation of social justice concerns arising from ecological despoliation. After reviewing liberation theology's early critique of economic developmentalism, as well as its more recent treatment of ecological concerns, this paper suggests that liberation theology is in fact positing a cosmological as well as political and economic critique of modernity, which proffers conduits of dialogue with other environmental approaches.

Bill McKibben underscores the "Christian" dimensions of the U.S. in his article,"The Christian Paradox: How a Faithful Nation Gets Jesus Wrong" (Harper's, August 2005, 31- 37). McKibben writes, "Ours is among the most spiritually homogenous rich nations on earth. Depending on which poll you look at and how the question is asked, somewhere around 85 percent of us call ourselves Christian. Israel, by way of comparison, is 77 percent Jewish. That's what America is: a place saturated in Christian identity" (32). Interestingly, McKibben faults mainline U.S. evangelical Christianity for not taking seriously Jesus' prime command to take care of the poor, suggesting that the Christian identity of the U.S. is a corruption of the central Christian message, i.e., to love your neighbor as yourself, especially the least among you.
The most celebrated of such critiques in an ecological context is cultural historianLynn White Jr., "The Historical Roots of Our Ecologic Crisis," Science 155 (1967): 1203-7.
The term is from H. Paul Santmire's title,The Travail of Nature: The Ambiguous Ecological Promise of Christianity (Philadelphia: Fortress, 1985).

fn.p: As Neil Smith argues, in the 1970s Rostow's Stages and other models of development and modernization "enjoyed the status of conventional wisdom" in geography departments among all but a handful of mainly "Marxist malcontents." Smith argues that "modernization was a mission, much as Christianization had been for many European colonists of the previous century." For Third World specialists, he writes, the question was not whether to sanction or advance modernization, but, rather, how to achieve this "unquestioned" good. One wonders if the same unquestioned "good" has been attached to notions of "globalization" and "sustainable development" within those same academic corridors that Smith trod in the 1970s. (Neil Smith, "The Satanic Geographies of Globalization: Uneven Development in the 1990s," Public Culture 10 (1) (1997: 169-189), 172.

fn.p: Frank writes: "It is generally held that economic development occurs in a succession of capitalist stages and that today's underdeveloped countries are still in a stage through which now-developed countries passed long ago. Yet even a modest acquaintance with history shows that the underdevelopment is not original or traditional and that neither the past nor the present of the underdeveloped countries resemble in any important respect the past of the now-developed countries. The now-developed countries were never underdeveloped, though they may have been undeveloped. It is also widely believed that the contemporary underdevelopment of a country can be understood as the product of reflection solely of its own economic, political, social, and cultural characteristics of structure.Capitalism and Underdevelopment in Latin America (New York: Monthly Review Press, 1967), 5.

Frank writes: "Dialectically integrated society and economy which today obliges the bourgeoisie—including its most nationalist sectors—to pursue policies which, however much development they may generate for the minority, condemn the majority of Latin Americans to ever-deeper underdevelopment, and the bourgeoisie itself to increasing dependence on and absorption into the metropolitan bourgeoisie of the neo-imperialist system." In his more recent work, Frank attempts to understand economic systems from a global rather than Eurocentric perspective, and argues that the modern rise of Europe may be seen as a mere blip on a world economic landscape dominated by Asia.
